title: My wife was injured and I have a $46,000 bill from an airvac ambulance. What am I liable for
question: She was injured in a bit of a remote area. The ambulance stopped about half way through the trip and stated they needed assistance from an airvac, It was about 21 miles from the hospital at this point. I received a bill from the airvac for $46,000 for the trip. After a back and forth with the the insurance and airvac company, the insurance reimburse them for about $10,000. After speaking with the airvac, the best they would do is lower the bill to 19,000 after the insurance. I have paid all outstanding bills to hospital , doctor, ambulance etc. I have just received a bill from collection with a $2400 late charge so the bill is about $38,000 dollars right now. What is my responsibility for the airvac. I did not contact them the ambulance did. What are my options other than filling for bankruptcy? Which type of lawyer would be able to best assist me with this? Thank you in advance.
answers:
You are liable for your wife's debt. However, you may have a bad-faith insurance claim if the services are covered by your insurance plan and the company is not allowing enough for a reasonably necessary medical expense. The devil is always in the details of your coverage limits. Check into that.

If you cannot settle this debt for what you can afford to pay, and especially if you owe additional debts, Bankruptcy is certainly an option. You and your wife are entitled to a discharge of this kind of debt. Whether you can file a Chapter 7 or a Chapter 13 is something for which you should seek qualified counsel. Use AVVO's Find a Lawyer tab to find a well-reviewed and experienced attorney to speak with about bad-faith insurance claims or Bankruptcy. I'll change this category to Bankruptcy and Debt, but do look into bad-faith attorney potential.

You’re liable for all of it. It doesn’t matter that the ambulance company called them, so long as it was reasonably medically necessary. You can continue trying to settle it, and I suggest you contact a bankruptcy attorney to assist.since they’re more likely to negotiate if they believe you actually may file bankruptcy. People just calling and claiming they will, the air company won’t give much credence to.

California Family Code Section states you are liable for a "debt incurred for necessaries of life of the person's spouse before the date of separation of the spouses". Emergency medical treatment arguably could qualify as one of the "necessaries of life" and you could be held liable in a lawsuit.

Any debt can potentially be settled and medical debt is no different. You should contact a debt settlement or bankruptcy attorney for further assistance.
